cab.content: Thlo r*o^!j*r^nt is the Property of telegrams-" SHIPMINDER, VIC, LONDON."evern merit1 *iAny further communication on this subject should be addressed to The Secretary,Ministry of Shipping,St. James's Park, London, S.W. 1, and the following number quoted.MINISTRY OF SHIPPING,4th November, 1918.Mr. \%T. )In continuation of my letter of the 28th ultimoI am directed by the Shipping Controller to report, forthe information of the War Cabinet, as follows:-1.LOSSES AND GAINS OP BRITISH TONNAGEDuring the week ended the 26th ultimo no British vessels were sunk by enemy action; three vessels of 11,411 gross tons were, however, lost by marine peril.During the same period 8 new vessels of 36,372 gross tons, British built, were brought into service and 4 new vessels were purchased overseas, thus making a net gain of 9 ships of 39,359 gross tons.There were no British ships of any kind lost by enemy attack in October after the 21st of that month. 2. FIMMCEThe amount paid in compensation for loss of requisitionedships during the week ended the 26th ultimo was 785,615,making a total of 36,328,391 paid on this account sincethe 1st April, 1918.THE SECRETARY,'VkK CABINET, COAL position with reference to paragraph 4 of ray letter of the 7th ultimo regarding the coal position, the output from South T;ale3 has increased, in spite of the epidemic of Influenza.Hie tonnage at present available is becoming insufficient to meet the demand, and keep all the Collieries working at full pressure. In the Tyne, the coal output continues to be good, but the tonnage is sufficient.Shipments from South Africa are at a standstill o?.ring to Influenza.The Italian programme has again been met, but the French programme continues in arrears partly on account of the recent congestion at the ports, but more particu-larly owing to lack of tonnage of suitable size for the shallow ports, vhich has been aggravated by 4the diversion of extra vessels into the London trade at the urgent request of the President of the Board of Trade. STOPSS FOR THE BRITISH ARHY IN FKANCg .The quantity of Military stores discharged in France in the reel: ending 26th October was 200,328 tons, compared with 174,501 tons in the previous reel-:, EXCHANGE OF BRITISH AND GERMAN PRISONERS OF WAR.,The twenty-sixth exchange of prisoners of war has taken place, the Dutch ships disembarking 631 British prisoners at Boston on the 23rd ultimo, and embarking 466 German prisoners the following day,I am, Sir,Your obedient Servant, JOHN ANDERSON.
